element.name: DocumentReference
element.formal: A reference to a document.
element.comments: Usually, this is used for documents other than those defined by FHIR.

constraint.name: Location
constraint.human: A location or a service (or both) SHALL be provided

element.formal: The logical id of the resource, as used in the url for the resoure. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.formal: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the url. This values changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
element.comments: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

element.short: When the resource version last changed
element.formal: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
element.comments: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant.

element.short: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
element.formal: A list of profiles that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to Profile.url.
element.comments: It is up to the server and/or other infrastruture of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over tiem.

element.short: Security Labels applied to this resource
element.formal: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
element.comments: The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.formal: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
element.comments: The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.formal: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.formal: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal:
Globally unique identifier assigned to the document by the creating entity.
A DocumentEntry representing a single document is identified by the uniqueId attribute; the linkage between DocumentEntry and the Document it represents is made with the uniqueId attribute.
This unique identifier may be used in other documents to reference this document.
Other identifiers for the document.
element.comments:
Other identifiers can also include Identifiers may be Accession Numbers, Order Numbers, Referral Request 
Identifiers, XDS Workflow Instance Identifiers.

element.formal: The patientId represents the subject of care of the document.  The value of the patientId shall be the same for all new documents of a SubmissionSet. Patient information typically includes: the patient first and last name, sex, and birth date.
element.comments: In the context of XDS, the patientId shall be the one with use = official. The Clinical XDS Affinity Domain policies may require more or less specific information and format. This patient information is not intended to be updated once the Document is registered (just as the Document content and metadata itself will not be updated without replacing the previous document). As sourcePatientInfo may have been updated by the source actor, it may no longer be in use within the Document Source (EHR-CR). It is only intended as an audit/checking mechanism and has occasional use for Document Consumer actors.

mapping.map: PID-3-Patient ID List (No standard way to define a Practitioner or Group subject in V2 MDM message)
PID-3-Patient ID List (No standard way to define a Practitioner or Group subject in V2 MDM message)

element.formal: The code specifying the particular kind of document (e.g., Prescription, Discharge Summary, Report). It is suggested that the XDS Affinity Domain draws these values from a coding scheme providing a coarse level of granularity (about 10 to 100 entries). Shall have a single value.
element.comments: Key metadata element describing the document, used in searching/filtering.

element.formal: A categorization for the type of the document. This may be implied by or derived from the code specified in the Document Type.
element.comments: XDSDocumentEntry.typeCode.

element.formal: Represents the humans and/or machines that authored the document.
element.comments: Not necessarily who did the actual data entry (i.e. typist) it in or who was the source (informant).

mapping.map: TXA-9-Originator Code/Name (No standard way to indicate a Device in V2 MDM message)
TXA-9-Originator Code/Name (No standard way to indicate a Device in V2 MDM message)

element.formal: Org which maintains the document.
element.comments: Identifies the logical organization to go to find the current version, where to report issues, etc. This is different from the physical location of the document, which is the technical location of the document, which host may be delegated to the management of some other organization.

element.formal: A globally unique identifier for a community with which this document is associated.

Represents a participant who has legally authenticated or attested the document within the authorInstitution. Legal authentication implies that a document has been signed manually or electronically by the legalAuthenticator.
Represents the time the author created the document in the Document Source.
element.comments: Creation time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching. This is the creation time of the document, not the source material on which it is based.

element.short: XDS submission time or XDSDocumentEntry.creationTime  if unknown
element.formal: When this document reference created.
element.comments: Referencing/indexing time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching.

element.formal: This attribute is always set to Approved as part of the submission of new XDS Documents. It may be changed to Deprecated under the primary responsibility of the Document Source with possible patient supervision. Although XDS supports the ability to delete documents, there is no such state as ???the Document Entry is removed??? (only an audit trail is kept if such a deletion is allowed).

binding.name: DocumentReferenceStatus
binding.description: The status of the document reference

element.formal: Status of the underlying document.

element.short: Relationships that this document has with other document references that already exist
element.formal: Relationships to other documents.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: The type of relationship that this document has with anther document
element.formal: supercedes | transforms | signs | appends.
element.comments: If this document appends another document, then the document cannot be fully understood without also accessing the referenced document.

binding.name: DocumentRelationshipType
binding.description: The type of relationship between documents

element.short: The target document of this relationship
element.formal: Target of the relationship.
Represents the title of the document.
element.comments: What the document is about, rather than a terse summary of the document. It is commonly the case that records do not have a title and are collectively referred to by the display name of Record code (e.g. a "consultation" or "progress note").
element.requirements: Helps humans to assess whether the document is of interest.

element.formal: The code specifying the level of confidentiality of the XDS Document. These codes are specific to an XDS Affinity Domain.
element.comments: Enforcement and issues related to highly sensitive documents are beyond the scope of XDS (see security section). confidentialityCode is part of a codification scheme and value set enforced by the Document Registry.

binding.name: DocumentConfidentiality
binding.description: Codes specifying the level of confidentiality of the composition

element.formal: Specifies the human language of character data in the document. The values of the attribute are language identifiers as described by the IETF (Internet Engineering Task Force) RFC 3066.
element.comments: This value may further be restricted by the registry according to XDS Affinity Domain specific policy.

element.formal: MIME type of the document in the Repository.
element.comments: Note: application/hl7-v3+xml for CDA. application/binary for proprietary record formats.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.description: The mime type of an attachment

element.formal: Code globally uniquely specifying the format of the document. Along with the typeCode, it should provide sufficient information to allow any potential XDS Document Consumer to know if it will be able to process the document. The formatCode shall be sufficiently specific to ensure processing/display by identifying a document encoding, structure and template (e.g., for a CDA Document, the fact that it complies with a CDA schema, possibly a template and the choice of a content-specific style sheet).
element.comments: Format codes may be specified by multiple organizations. Format codes defined by ITI shall have names with the prefix urn:ihe:iti:. Format codes defined by other IHE domains shall have names with the prefix urn:ihe:???domain initials???: Format codes defined by the Affinity Domain shall have names with the prefix urn:ad:???name of affinity domain???: Affinity Domains shall be unique. The prefixes described here are not assumed to be exhaustive.

element.formal: Size in bytes of the byte stream that was provided in the Register and Provide Transaction and stored by the XDS Document Repository. This value is computed by the Document Repository and included in the Register Documents Set Transaction.
Hash key of the XDS Document itself.
element.comments: This value is computed by the Document Repository and used by the Document Registry for detecting the improper resubmission of XDS Documents. If present, shall have a single value. If this attribute is received in a Provide & Register Document Set-b [ITI-41] transaction, it shall be verified by the repository with the actual hash value of the submitted document; an XDSRepositoryMetadataError shall be returned on mismatch.

element.formal: Where to access the document.

mapping.map: (Might include V2 TXA-16-Unique Document File Name or TXA-24-Folder Assignment)
(Might include V2 TXA-16-Unique Document File Name or TXA-24-Folder Assignment)

element.short: can be determined from repository location + parameters
element.formal: If access is not fully described by location.
element.comments: If a document can be accessed by either a service or directly by a URL (i.e. an XDS repository with an MHD access point, or a DICOM network with a WADO portal) just provide the URL.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.formal: The type of the service that can be used to access the documents.
element.comments: The meaning and interpretation of the parameters depends on the service type.

element.short: Where service is located (usually a URL)
element.formal: Where the service end-point is located.
element.comments: Usually this is a URL, but for some services, the end-point is a simple network name or address that is not a valid URL.

element.formal: A list of named parameters that is used in the service call.
element.comments: The interpretation of the parameters, and how to convert them into a proper service call, is dependent on the type of the service, and needs to be specified in an implementation guide somewhere.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.formal: The name of a parameter.
The value of the named parameter.

element.short: event codes, service Start & Stop time, and facility type
element.formal: Clinical context of document - eventCodeList, serviceStart & Stop time, and facility type.
element.comments: These values are primarily added to help with searching for interesting/relevant documents.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.formal: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented. In some cases, the event is inherent in the typeCode, such as a "History and Physical Report" in which the procedure being documented is necessarily a "History and Physical" act.
element.comments: An event can further specialize the act inherent in the typeCode, such as where it is simply "Procedure Report" and the procedure was a "colonoscopy". If one or more eventCodes are included, they shall not conflict with the values inherent in the classCode, practiceSettingCode or typeCode, as such a conflict would create an ambiguous situation. This short list of codes is provided to be used as ???key words??? for certain types of queries.

binding.name: DocumentEventType
binding.description: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts being documented

element.formal: The start and stop time of the service being documented took place.
element.comments: At least a start date SHALL be provided.

element.formal: This code represents the type of organizational setting of the clinical encounter during which the documented act occurred.
element.comments: In some cases, the setting of the encounter is inherent in the typeCode, such as "Diabetes Clinic Progress Note". healthcareFacilityTypeCode shall be equivalent to or further specialize the value inherent in the typeCode; for example, where the typeCode is simply "Clinic Progress Note" and the value of healthcareFacilityTypeCode is "private clinic". The value shall not conflict with the value inherent in the typeCode, as such a conflict would create an ambiguous situation.

element.name: DocumentReference
element.formal: A reference to a document.

Globally unique identifier assigned to the document by the creating entity.
A DocumentEntry representing a single document is identified by the uniqueId attribute; the linkage between DocumentEntry and the Document it represents is made with the uniqueId attribute.
This unique identifier may be used in other documents to reference this document.
Other identifiers for the document.

The patientId represents the subject of care of the document.  The value of the patientId shall be the same for all new documents of a SubmissionSet. Patient information typically includes: the patient first and last name, sex, and birth date.
element.comments: In the context of XDS, the patientId shall be the one with use = official. The Clinical XDS Affinity Domain policies may require more or less specific information and format. This patient information is not intended to be updated once the Document is registered (just as the Document content and metadata itself will not be updated without replacing the previous document). As sourcePatientInfo may have been updated by the source actor, it may no longer be in use within the Document Source (EHR-CR). It is only intended as an audit/checking mechanism and has occasional use for Document Consumer actors.

element.formal: The code specifying the particular kind of document (e.g., Prescription, Discharge Summary, Report). It is suggested that the XDS Affinity Domain draws these values from a coding scheme providing a coarse level of granularity (about 10 to 100 entries). Shall have a single value.
A categorization for the type of the document. This may be implied by or derived from the code specified in the Document Type.
element.comments: XDSDocumentEntry.typeCode.

element.formal: Represents the humans and/or machines that authored the document.
Org which maintains the document.
A globally unique identifier for a community with which this document is associated.

Represents a participant who has legally authenticated or attested the document within the authorInstitution. Legal authentication implies that a document has been signed manually or electronically by the legalAuthenticator.
Represents the time the author created the document in the Document Source.

element.short: XDS submission time or XDSDocumentEntry.creationTime  if unknown
element.formal: When this document reference created.

This attribute is always set to Approved as part of the submission of new XDS Documents. It may be changed to Deprecated under the primary responsibility of the Document Source with possible patient supervision. Although XDS supports the ability to delete documents, there is no such state as ???the Document Entry is removed??? (only an audit trail is kept if such a deletion is allowed).
Status of the underlying document.

element.formal: Relationships to other documents.

element.comments: Enforcement and issues related to highly sensitive documents are beyond the scope of XDS (see security section). confidentialityCode is part of a codification scheme and value set enforced by the Document Registry.

element.formal: Specifies the human language of character data in the document. The values of the attribute are language identifiers as described by the IETF (Internet Engineering Task Force) RFC 3066.
element.comments: This value may further be restricted by the registry according to XDS Affinity Domain specific policy.

element.formal: MIME type of the document in the Repository.

Code globally uniquely specifying the format of the document. Along with the typeCode, it should provide sufficient information to allow any potential XDS Document Consumer to know if it will be able to process the document. The formatCode shall be sufficiently specific to ensure processing/display by identifying a document encoding, structure and template (e.g., for a CDA Document, the fact that it complies with a CDA schema, possibly a template and the choice of a content-specific style sheet).
element.comments: Format codes may be specified by multiple organizations. Format codes defined by ITI shall have names with the prefix urn:ihe:iti:. The prefixes described here are not assumed to be exhaustive.

element.formal: Size in bytes of the byte stream that was provided in the Register and Provide Transaction and stored by the XDS Document Repository. This value is computed by the Document Repository and included in the Register Documents Set Transaction.
Hash key of the XDS Document itself.
element.comments: This value is computed by the Document Repository and used by the Document Registry for detecting the improper resubmission of XDS Documents. If present, shall have a single value.
